transcripts.transcript: The disengagement between Chinese and Indian troops along the line of actual control in Ladakh has begun. But many are asking that what led to the Chinese decision to withdraw and withdraw so quickly from the areas that they had made massive ingress along the line of actual control since April last year, a broad assessment would tell us that the Chinese are looking to have conveyed to New Delhi. They point that they do not take the assertions by India that the entire territory of Ladakh includes excision and the fact that China is an adversary that India was willing to take on with the Americans. China has conveyed its point, but equally India has also conveyed a point to the Chinese that the Indian military is not the military of 1962 and the Indian leadership is not the leadership of 1962 where we bungled our way into the conflict with the Chinese and where we did not let our military fight. One of the redeeming features of this entire standoff has been the decision of the Modi government to largely leave matters to the military and in fact they did not allow the situation to escalate even by not naming the Chinese as the aggressors, but conveyed that the era of expansionism is over. What is more important is that India dug its heels in and made it known that as far as India was concerned, no part of Indian territory was negotiable. And where the lines have come to be the perceived lines which are called the line of actual control, those lines will be respected by both sides. That was the defining position of India in all the talks that went on with the Chinese to say that unless that principle is respected, there is not going to be a cooling down of pressure between the two sides. Also, the nine rounds of talks and soon to be the 10th round of talks have largely been led by the corps commanders from the Indian side, and a co commander is a left general who is responsible for a large sector where operations can be conducted, and he has troops to the range of 40 to 50,000 soldiers fully equipped and trained for war. China realised that the Indian army is not a pushover. India's military commanders know what they're talking about and Delhi gave them the support that they required. And unlike earlier rounds of many negotiations with the Chinese, which is largely held at the terms of engagement laid down by the Indian Ministry of External Affairs based on the advice of the military and the China Study Group and various others in this case the Ministry of External Affairs did provide, particularly from the months of October, November December, a additional secretary level officer who came in as an observer and giving a sort of guidance to the military commanders. But the military commanders had very clear directions from the higher military authorities in Delhi as to what were India's terms and what they could not concede on. So the Chinese achieved a couple of things. The first is this entire area that we are hearing about, which is in the range of about, um, anything in the range of about 10 kilometres plus minus, where there is a controversy that why finger four and finger eight are not being patrolled Now we need to understand a few specifics. The entire Chinese ingress on the L AC over the last 8 to 10 months
